_header: And I it lose and you it find
Note: See 2368: apparently this was of common occurrence in the fifteenth century.
Bibliographic Ghosts:
San Marino, CA, Henry Huntington Library HM 140 [olim Phillipps 8299], f. 170v (referenced in Hanna (1980)
XHanna, Ralph. “The Index of Middle English Verse and Huntington Library Collections: A Checklist of Addenda.” Publications of the Bibliographical Society of America 74 (1980): 235-58, n. 1; but see 5660; London, British Library Addit. 39659: see 2368-2.

BodLye16.Transcription:
Iohn brack own this bookeyf I it loost and you it findeI prai
                    you take so muche paineas to bringe me my booke againe

BLCottTitCXIX.Transcription:
Thys ys Iohn Orms bookeAnd he hyt loose and you hyt fyndI praye
                    you hertile…

BLEge1151.Transcription:
Mysterys felys owyth thys bokeAnd she yt lose and you yt fyndeI
                    pray you to take the payneTo brynge my boke home agayne

BLHar1251.Transcription: and I yt los and yow yt fyndI pray yow hartely to be so kyndthat yow wol take a letel payneto se my boke brothe home agayne
BLHar1251.Note: Added to back flyleaf by same hand as 5560 at front; preceded by note of ownership, “Thys boke ys myne eleanour worcestar,” then signed on f. 185 “E worcester.”
